Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

What is the overall percentage of patients ages 12-18 in your practice with sleep problems?
Sleep is controlled by two processes - a homeostatic process and a circadian process.
Circadian rhythms pertain to physical, mental, and behavioral changes that follow a roughly 24-hour cycle.
Circadian rhythms are not influenced by light and darkness.
The recommended amount of sleep for teenagers is 6-8 hours every night.
Research suggests the optimal amount of sleep for adolescents in 9.25 hours.
Adolescents do not need as much sleep as younger children.
Circadian rhythms and sleep-wake timing tend to shift later during adolescence.
The timing of melatonin release is not changed in adolescents as compared to younger children.
Increasing demands of adolescence (e.g., homework, extracurricular activities) and early school start times make it hard for many teens to get the recommended amount of sleep.
''Catching up'' on sleep by sleeping in significantly later on the weekends is helpful to adolescent sleep.
Adolescents with insomnia will report difficulty falling asleep but not difficulty staying asleep or waking too early in the morning.
Adolescents with delayed sleep phase (''Night Owls'') may present with difficulty falling asleep.
Adolescents with delayed sleep phase may present with difficulty waking up on time for school.
Depressed adolescents may present with difficulty sleeping OR sleeping too much OR both.
Disturbed sleep among adolescents does not impact their risk of subsequently developing depression.
A meaningful difference between weekday sleep timing and weekend sleep timing can have negative consequences for adolescents.
Health care providers should recommend that adolescents get out of bed if they are not asleep for more than 30 minutes when trying to sleep.
Health care providers should not recommend temporary establishment of a later bedtime as an intervention for an adolescent with difficulty falling asleep.
Bright light therapy (with a light box or natural light) may be helpful for adolescents with a delayed sleep phase.
It is normal for adolescents to awaken briefly during the night at the end of each sleep cycle (several times throughout the night).
Among your adolescent patients (ages 12-18), how often do you assess for sleep problems/patterns as part of a behavioral health intake evaluation?
Notes: 1= 0-25% of the time; 2= 26-50% of the time; 3= 51-75% of the time; 4= 76-100% of the time
